content: How can I help you today?
I’m not really sure where to start… things at home are just so overwhelming. My wife thought this might help, but honestly, I’m really skeptical about how talking is going to change anything.

It sounds like things have been really overwhelming for you at home, and it's understandable to feel skeptical about whether talking can make a difference. Taking this step, even with some hesitation, shows a lot of strength. What's been feeling most overwhelming for you lately?

I guess it’s my son. He’s been acting out a lot, and my wife and I can’t seem to figure out how to help him. It’s putting so much strain on our marriage, and honestly, I feel like I’m losing everything—my focus at work, time with my daughter, and even the connection with my wife. It’s all just too much.

That sounds really heavy to carry—you’re dealing with concerns about your son, the strain on your marriage, and feeling like so many important parts of your life are slipping away. It’s clear how much you care about your family and how deeply this is affecting you. What’s been most difficult for you in trying to support your son and navigate everything else at the same time?

I think it’s the feeling of failure—that I can’t seem to help him or fix what’s going on. I try to be there for him, but nothing seems to work, and it’s heartbreaking. And at the same time, it’s pulling me further away from everything else I care about, and I don’t know how to manage it all.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot of responsibility and feeling stuck between wanting to be the best parent for your son while also trying to hold onto the other connections and parts of your life that matter to you. That feeling of trying everything and not seeing progress can be heartbreaking and exhausting. It’s clear how deeply invested you are in being there for your family. What keeps you motivated or gives you strength, even in the middle of all of this?

I think it’s just knowing that, deep down, I want to keep my family together. No matter how hard it feels, I don’t want to give up on my son, my wife, or my daughter. It’s what keeps me going, even when I’m completely drained.

That determination to keep your family together says a lot about your values and the love you have for them, even when it feels overwhelming and draining. It sounds like no matter how tough things get, your commitment to your family gives you purpose. What feels like the biggest obstacle right now in finding a way forward?

I think it’s that I just don’t know what the right thing to do is anymore. Every time I try something, it feels like it either doesn’t help or makes things worse, and it’s just exhausting. It’s like I’m stuck and can’t see the way out of this.

Feeling stuck can be exhausting, especially when you’re trying everything you can and not getting the results you hope for. It really shows how much you care about your son and your family, even when it feels like you’re unsure of the right path. What would it mean for you to find clarity or even small steps forward in this situation?

I guess it would mean not feeling so powerless all the time, like I’m actually making a difference and not failing them every step of the way. Even small steps would help, but I just have no idea what those steps are supposed to be right now. It’s hard to see a way forward on my own.

It sounds like finding even small steps forward—not feeling powerless—would really help you feel more like you’re making a difference and being the parent and partner you want to be. It’s okay to feel unsure; you’re trying to navigate such a complex situation, and that takes courage. Is there anything else you’d like to share about what you’ve been going through before we talk about finding those small steps?
I think I’ve shared the main points. It’s really just the feeling of failing everyone and not knowing how to fix it that’s weighing on me. What kind of steps could even help in a situation like this?

Thanks for sharing so openly—these are really tough feelings you’re carrying, and it’s clear how much you want to find ways to be there for your family. You’ve mentioned feeling stuck and wanting to regain a sense of being effective and connected. Here’s what’s been shared so far: you’re dedicated to keeping your family together despite the emotional toll, you’ve been struggling to find approaches that make a difference for your son, and you want to break free from feeling powerless and overwhelmed.

Would it be okay to start exploring ways to identify small, achievable steps that could help you move closer to what matters most to you?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
